p: SerpinG1 is the C1 complement inhibitor (inhibiting the classical pathway of the complement) but also inhibits other proteases including MASP-1 and MASP-2 in the lectin pathway. Circulating SerpinG1 protein levels increase ~2.5 folds during inflammation [ 33]. Furthermore, during HIV infections, SerpinG1 mRNA levels increased in the circulating monocytes [ 24]. The lectin pathway has been implicated as causing the tissue damage during alphaviral arthritis caused by the Ross River virus [ 23], and SerpinG1 upregulation may act to limit such damage [ 34].
